CHAPTER 12: THE RECKONING

Date: January 29, 1431
Location: Royal Alcázar, Toledo

The morning sun filtered through the high windows of Juan's private study, casting long shadows across the floor. Outside, Toledo hummed with activity—noble households arriving daily for the wedding, their banners adding splashes of color to the city's ancient stone. But inside these walls, the air held a different tension.

Álvaro stood by the window, arms crossed, watching the courtyard below. "Three requests came in last night," he said quietly. "All from houses who've heard the whispers about what you'll announce at the wedding."

Juan looked up from the pile of correspondence on his desk. Letters from across Castile—some congratulatory about the marriage, others more carefully worded, probing for details about the "matters of crusade administration" to be discussed.

"Tell me."

Álvaro turned, his expression unreadable. "First: Don Íñigo López de Mendoza the Elder. Head of House Mendoza. He arrived yesterday with forty retainers and his son Pedro. He's requesting a private audience 'to better understand His Majesty's vision for the nobility's participation in the holy crusade.'" A slight pause. "His phrasing was very careful."

Juan nodded slowly. The Mendozas—one of the wealthiest and most powerful families in Castile. The younger Íñigo, the poet, served in Juan's own cabinet. But the elder Íñigo was a different matter entirely: pragmatic, calculating, immensely influential among the great houses.

"Second," Álvaro continued, "Don Enrique Enríquez, Admiral of Castile. He's concerned about how the papal taxation will affect the coastal holdings and wants to discuss 'clarification of certain provisions regarding service in lieu of payment.' He emphasized his family's long military service to the crown."

The Enríquez family—powerful in the north, with extensive estates and traditional claims to naval authority. Enrique himself was about forty, a competent administrator but no warrior. His concern would be protecting family wealth while appearing appropriately loyal.

"And third?" Juan asked, though he suspected he knew.

Álvaro's jaw tightened slightly. "Don Luis de Guzmán, Master of Santiago." He let that hang in the air for a moment. "He requests an audience to discuss 'the Military Orders' role in the coming campaign and matters of crusade administration affecting the Order's properties.'"

Juan leaned back in his chair. Luis de Guzmán—the man who had sided with the Infantes during their rebellion, who commanded two thousand Santiago knights, whose Order controlled vast estates across Castile. The same man whose political calculation had led him to support the wrong side of that conflict.

"He has considerable courage," Juan observed dryly, "requesting a private audience after supporting those who tried to undermine the crown."

"Or considerable desperation," Álvaro replied. "The Santiago properties are extensive. The ten percent church tax plus the five percent noble tax—if they assess his personal holdings alongside the Order's estates..." He shrugged. "It could be crushing. And the personal service exemption doesn't help him much—he's in his fifties, not exactly crusade material anymore."

Juan stood and walked to the window, looking out over Toledo. The city where his father had ruled, where the weight of Castilian history pressed down like the stones of the cathedral itself.

"What's your assessment?" he asked.

"Mendoza will be reasonable—he's always played the long game. He'll want clarity, perhaps some reassurance that the assessment will be fair, maybe hint at generous voluntary contributions beyond the tax if treated respectfully." Álvaro paused. "Enríquez will try to negotiate the details, find loopholes, perhaps offer naval service as a substitute. He's a bureaucrat at heart."

"And Guzmán?"

"Guzmán is cornered. The Order's estates are massive, and he can't claim poverty. He can't join the crusade personally without looking ridiculous—everyone knows he's past his prime. And he's politically isolated after backing the Infantes." Álvaro's expression hardened. "He'll either grovel and seek mercy, or he'll try to rally the other Masters to resist the church taxation as an affront to the Orders' privileges."

Juan turned back to face his Constable. "You think he'd risk open resistance?"

"I think he's frightened enough to be dangerous. But not strong enough to be effective." Álvaro moved closer, lowering his voice. "The question is what you want to accomplish with these meetings. They're testing you, Your Majesty. Every great house in Castile is watching to see if the king who returns from Rome is the same boy who left, or something... different."

The room fell silent save for the distant sounds of the city. Somewhere in the Alcázar, Isabel would be at her prayers in the Portuguese chapel, finding peace in the familiar rhythms of devotion. The banner and relics waited in their chamber, ready for the wedding ceremony. And in eighteen days, all of these nobles would gather in the cathedral to witness not just a marriage but an announcement that would define the next decade of Castilian history.

Juan looked at the three names Álvaro had mentioned. Three different approaches, three different pressures, three different tests of how he would wield the authority he'd fought so hard to claim.

"Schedule them," Juan said finally. "Mendoza first—this afternoon if he's available. Then Enríquez tomorrow morning. Guzmán..." He paused, considering. "Guzmán can wait until the day after. Let him think about it for a while longer."

Álvaro nodded, a slight smile touching his lips. "As you command, Your Majesty."

He turned to leave, but Juan called him back. "Álvaro. Your honest assessment—how many of the great houses will truly resist the taxation?"

The Constable was quiet for a long moment. "In private? All of them will hate it. In public?" He shrugged. "Perhaps five or six will make noise, seek special treatment, drag their feet on assessments. But open resistance? With the papal legate here, the banner unveiled, the crusade proclaimed at your wedding with all Castile watching?" He shook his head. "They're not stupid. They know the costs of being seen to oppose a holy crusade. They'll grumble, negotiate where they can, and ultimately comply."

"And if they don't?"

Álvaro met his gaze steadily. "Then you'll need to demonstrate that the crown's authority—and the Pope's—is not negotiable. But I don't think it will come to that. Not if you handle these meetings well."

After Álvaro left, Juan remained by the window. Below in the courtyard, servants unloaded chests from a newly arrived wagon—another noble household taking up residence for the wedding. In the streets beyond, pilgrims continued to arrive to see the banner, to pray before the relics, to offer themselves for the crusade.

Three audiences. Three tests. And behind them, scores of watching eyes from every great house in Castile, waiting to see how their young king would balance papal authority, noble privilege, and the demands of holy war.
